definition: to break the door down and enter (idiom)
broken/damaged/worn out/lousy/rotten/to break, split or cleave/to get rid of/to destroy/to break with/to defeat/to capture (a city etc)/to expose the truth of

gate/door/CL:扇[shan4]/gateway/doorway/CL:個|个[ge4]/opening/valve/switch/way to do something/knack/family/house/(religious) sect/school (of thought)/class/category/phylum or division (taxonomy)/classifier for large guns/classifier for lessons, subjects, branches of technology/(suffix) -gate (i.e. scandal; derived from Watergate)
surname Men
and/as well as/and so/but (not)/yet (not)/(indicates causal relation)/(indicates change of state)/(indicates contrast)
to enter/to go into/to join/to become a member of/to confirm or agree with/abbr. for 入聲|入声[ru4 sheng1]

sentences.english: It that man whose house was broken into by burglars last week?
sentences.chinese: 上周家里被盗贼破门而入的就是那个人吗？

sentences.english: After the thief broke in, there was almost nothing left in the room.
sentences.chinese: 小偷破门而入，屋里几乎被洗劫一空。

sentences.english: “Andrew's hut was broken into and some film was stolen,” she said.
sentences.chinese: 安德鲁的棚屋被破门而入，一些片子被偷了。

sentences.english: The firemen battered the door down and saved the children from the burning building.
sentences.chinese: 救火员破门而入，从燃烧著的大楼里救出了孩子们。

sentences.english: The cops busted into my room last weekend and caught my roommate smoking weed.
sentences.chinese: 我室友上个周末在房间抽大麻被警察破门而入抓包。

sentences.english: Robbers often break in at midnight.
sentences.chinese: 匪贼常常在半夜破门而入。

sentences.english: Secure your doors and windows so that burglars cannot break in.
sentences.chinese: 锁好门窗，以免窃贼破门而入。

sentences.english: Open up, or I break in.
sentences.chinese: 开门，要不然我就要破门而入了。

sentences.english: The policeman took the burglar by surprise as he broke into the house.
sentences.chinese: 盗贼正要破门而入时，警察出奇不意地把他抓住了。

definition: locked in (with the door locked from the outside)
to knock on a door
to break in/to force a door
evildoer/malefactor/gangster/hoodlum
to pick a lock/to force a lock
to rush out through a door (idiom)
to open a door (lit. and fig.)/to open for business
to swarm in (of people etc) (idiom)
bandit/robber
to break into a house when nobody is home
to rush in/to charge in
to resist arrest
thief
to call for help
to lock/to lock up
to escape without trace (idiom); to make one's getaway (from the scene of a crime)/to show a clean pair of heels
